Award.AwardTitle: Hazards SEES Type 2: Magnitude 9 Earthquake Scenarios - Probabilistic Modeling, Warnings, Response and Resilience in the Pacific Northwest
Award.AbstractNarration:
A Cascadia earthquake of magnitude 9 (M9) would cause shaking, liquefaction, landslides and tsunamis from British Columbia to northern California. The resulting losses, projected in the tens of billions of dollars, would include damaged buildings, bridges and lifelines, as well as thousands of human casualties. This project addresses scientific and engineering challenges in reducing this risk. The challenges start with assessing the range of distributions of fault motion and, therefore, the shaking and tsunamis that the Cascadia fault might generate. The project addresses factors not previously considered ? the distribution and timing of energy release on the fault, the coherent variation of frequency content of fault motion with fault depth, and the 3D effects of the deep basins along Puget Sound - and will specify the uncertainty in the estimated motions, which is critical to probabilistic estimation of earthquake impact, including liquefaction, landslides, tsunamis and built infrastructure response. The project will develop new probabilistic, statistical, and numerical methodologies to provide deeper insight into these phenomena. This research will improve forecasting of landslides and liquefaction through better resolution of the underlying physics with recent data from Japan and Chile. The project will also improve estimation of tsunami effects by developing more realistic scenarios of seafloor deformation and by estimating the battering power of entrained debris. Built-environment response to the unique long-period and long-duration ground motions will be evaluated probabilistically using advanced numerical simulation. To inform the development and deployment of earthquake early warning in the U.S., the project includes interview and survey research on the potential effects of messages that provide just a few seconds or minutes of warning. With local communities and agency partners, the project will improve the utility of probabilistic information by comparing how stakeholders interpret (a) single "worst case" hazard scenarios and (b) multiple probabilistic scenarios, and how each type of scenario is then incorporated into community emergency preparedness and long-range planning. The project will also advance the integration of probabilistic assessments into hazards education.

The last decade has provided unexpected lessons in the enormous risks from giant subduction earthquakes of M9. Sumatra 2004, Chile 2010, and Japan 2011 each caused devastation that took scientists and residents by surprise. M9 earthquakes in the Cascadia subduction zone pose the greatest natural hazard in the Pacific Northwest and provide an integrative focus for interdisciplinary research on reducing future losses to extreme events. To address challenges in risk reduction, this project brings together experts from academia, government, and other nonprofit organizations. The shared vision is to reduce the catastrophic risk of a Cascadia M9 earthquake through integrated advances in forecasting, warning and adaptive planning across the social, built and natural environments. The project will move beyond generalized scenarios toward probabilistic predictions of M9 seismic events and the subsequent hazards, with the objective of integrating these into community resilience planning and advancing the state of earthquake early warning systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the last two decades we’ve seen the enormous risks from great subduction earthquakes: Sumatra 2004, Chile 2010, and Japan 2011 were each devastating.  Similar megaquakes are known to occur on the Cascadia subduction zone (CSZ), “The Really Big One” could rupture the entire 1100 km length of the Pacific Northwest plate boundary, from Canada to California. 

Our NSF-funded Hazards SEES project brought together a diverse team, spanning the academy, public and nonprofit sectors. Our vision was to reduce the catastrophic potential of a CSZ Magnitude 9 (M9) event through integrated research advances in prediction, warning and adaptive planning across the social, built and natural environments, and across time scales, from the seconds of preparation provided by an earthquake early warning, to the years of planning involved in land use and zoning decisions. So-called “M9” project research advanced hazard sciences by moving away from generalized scenarios toward probabilistic predictions of M9 seismic events and the hazards they trigger, integrating these predictions into community resilience planning, and advancing the state of earthquake early warning systems. M9 Cascadia megaquakes provided an integrative focus for the project’s interdisciplinary hazards and risk research, relevant to a broad range of hazards and extreme events.  

M9 researchers ran 3D simulations on supercomputers, producing 50 Cascadia earthquake realizations that are now publicly available on DesignSafe, an NSF facility.  Realizations in which the earthquake is rupturing away from versus toward the coast produce very different time histories. Further, the simulations show amplified shaking in the Seattle basin and other basins, compared to other locations along the west coast. These simulations were used to study the impacts of M9 events on buildings and infrastructure, liquefaction, and landslides.  This led to revised recommendations for the design of tall buildings in Seattle.  

M9 studies also produced a new catalogue of landslides on the Oregon coast, demonstrated a new method for determining the age of landslides in that catalogue, and advanced understanding of landslide risks from earthquakes in Seattle and within the coastal mountains of Oregon and Washington, showing, for example, that wet weather increases such risks considerably. The project also advanced probabilistic modeling of tsunami inundation scenarios. These scenarios were integrated into interdisciplinary training on mapping hazard information with uncertainties, and the resulting hazard maps were used in community planning and hazard mitigation workshops.   In a cost benefit analysis, the project also demonstrated the net benefits of earthquake early warning for Washington State, and advanced understanding of how perceptions influence earthquake preparedness and preferences for earthquake early warning. 

In addition to specific scientific advances, the M9 project has already led to the development of several related research projects, and contributed to: reassessment of building codes for tall buildings; integration of hazard planning into comprehensive community plans; and development of ShakeAlert earthquake early warning communications and messaging.  

Over the course of the project, M9 leadership also worked with community partners onnumerous education and outreach endeavors, including multiple technical workshops on various aspects of the research project, an extremely well attended public lecture series on hazards and disasters, a popular Burke Museum-hosted short course for the public on hazards, a multi-day interdisciplinary graduate-student workshop on tsunami modeling and representing uncertainties in tsunami hazard maps, several regional stakeholders meetings, and a regular (biweekly) M9 seminar, open to all who registered for the M9 listserv. 

In sum, the M9 project integrated seismology, tsunami, landslide and liquefaction observations and modeling, engineering, planning, decision and policy sciences in a probabilistic analysis and modeling framework to achieve advances in forecasting, warnings, and adaptive planning across the social, built, and natural environments, in order to enhance resilience to megathrust earthquakes and related hazards. The project identified opportunities for improving seismic risk management and mitigation, earthquake and tsunami warnings, planning and preparedness in over 50 publications and presentations, and provided training for three postdoctoral researchers, 10 graduate research assistants, and four undergraduates.
